metadata.title: Isolation and characterization of a bat SARS-like coronavirus that uses the ACE2 receptor

body_text.text: Bats were trapped in their natural habitat as described previously5. Throat and fecal swab samples were collected in viral transport medium (VTM) composed of Hank’s balanced salt solution at pH7.4 containing BSA (1%), amphotericin (15 μg/ml), penicillin G (100 U/ml), and streptomycin (50 μg/ml). To collect fresh fecal samples, clean plastic sheets measuring 2.0 by 2.0 m were placed under known bat roosting sites at about 18:00 hours each evening. Relatively fresh fecal samples were collected from sheets at approximately 5:30 to 6:00 the next morning and placed in VTM. Samples were transported to the laboratory and stored at −80°C until use. All animals trapped for this study were released back to their habitat after sample collection. All sampling processes were performed by veterinarians with approval from Animal Ethics Committee of the Wuhan Institute of Virology and EcoHealth Alliance under an inter-institutional agreement with UC Davis.

RNA was extracted from 140 μl of swab or fecal samples with Viral RNA Mini Kit (Qiagen) following the manufacturer’s instructions. RNA was eluted in 60 μl AVE buffer, then aliquoted and stored at −80°C. One-step RT-PCR (Invitrogen) was used to detect coronavirus sequences as described previously15. First round PCR was conducted in a 25-μl reaction mix containing 12.5 μl PCR 2 x reaction mix Buffer, 10 pmol of each primer, 2.5 mM MgSO4, RNase Inhibitor 20 U, 1 μl SuperScript III/Platinum Taq Enzyme Mix, and 5 μl RNA. Amplification of the RdRp-gene fragment was performed as follows: 50°C for 30 min, 94°C for 2 min, followed by 40 cycles consisting of 94°C for 15 sec, 62°C for 15 sec, 68°C for 40 sec, and a final extension of 68°C for 5 min. Second round PCR was conducted in a 25-μl reaction mix containing 2.5 μl PCR reaction buffer, 5 pmol of each primer, 50 mM MgCl2, 0.5 mM dNTP, 0.1 μl Platinum Taq Enzyme (Invitrogen), and 1 μl first round PCR product. The amplification of RdRp-gene fragment was performed as follows: 94°C for 5 min followed by 35 cycles consisting of 94°C for 30 sec, 52°C for 30 sec, 72°C for 40 sec, and a final extension of 72°C for 5 min.
body_text.section: RNA extraction, PCR and sequencing ::: METHODS

body_text.text: To amplify the RBD region, one-step RT-PCR was performed with primers designed based on available SARS-CoV or bat SL-CoVs (first round PCR primers:
body_text.section: RNA extraction, PCR and sequencing ::: METHODS

body_text.text: CoVS1805R-5′-ACATCYTGATANARAACAGC-3′). First round PCR was conducted in a 25-μl reaction mix as described above except primers specific for the S gene were used. The amplification of the RBD region of the S gene was performed as follows: 50°C for 30 min, 94°C for 2 min, followed by 35 cycles consisting of 94°C for 15 sec, 43°C for 15 sec, 68°C for 90 sec, and a final extension of 68°C for 5 min. Second round PCR was conducted in a 25-μl reaction mix containing 2.5 μl PCR reaction Buffer, 5 pmol of each primer, 50 mM MgCl2, 0.5 mM dNTP, 0.1 μl Platinum Taq Enzyme (Invitrogen), and 1 μl first round PCR product. Amplification was performed as follows: 94°C for 5 min followed by 40 cycles consisting of 94°C for 30 sec, 41°C for 30 sec, 72°C for 60 sec, and a final extension of 72°C for 5 min.
body_text.section: RNA extraction, PCR and sequencing ::: METHODS

body_text.text: PCR products were gel purified and cloned into pGEM-T Easy Vector (Promega). At least four independent clones were sequenced to obtain a consensus sequence for each of the amplified regions.
body_text.section: RNA extraction, PCR and sequencing ::: METHODS

body_text.text: Degenerate coronavirus primers were designed based on all available SARS-CoV and bat SL-CoV sequences in GenBank and specific primers were designed from genome sequences generated from previous rounds of sequencing in this study (primer sequences will be provided upon request). All PCRs were conducted using One-Step RT-PCR kit (Invitrogen). The 5′ and 3′ genomic ends were determined using 5′ or 3′ RACE kit (Roche), respectively. PCR products were gel purified and sequenced directly or following cloning into pGEM-T Easy Vector (Promega). At least four independent clones were sequenced to obtain a consensus sequence for each of the amplified regions and each region was sequenced at least twice.

Routine sequence management and analysis was carried out using DNAStar or Geneious. Sequence alignment and edit was conducted using ClustalW, BioEdit or GeneDoc. Maximum Likelihood phylogenetic trees based on the protein sequences were constructed using a Poisson model with bootstrap values determined by 1,000 replicates in the MEGA5 software package.
body_text.section: Sequence analysis and databank accession numbers ::: METHODS

body_text.text: Sequences obtained in this study have been deposited in GenBank as follows (accession numbers given in parenthesis): full-length genome sequence of SL-CoV RsSHC014 and Rs3367 (KC881005, KC881006); full-length sequence of WIV1 S (KC881007); RBD (KC880984-KC881003); ACE2(KC8810040). SARS-CoV sequences used in this study: human SARS-CoV strains Tor2 (AY274119), BJ01 (AY278488), GZ02 (AY390556), and civet SARS-CoV strain SZ3 (AY304486). Bat coronavirus sequences used in this study: Rs672 (FJ588686), Rp3 (DQ071615), Rf1 (DQ412042), Rm1 (DQ412043), HKU3-1 (DQ022305), BM48-31 (NC_014470), HKU9-1 (NC_009021), HKU4 (NC_009019), HKU5 (NC_009020), HKU8 (DQ249228), HKU2 (EF203067), BtCoV512 (NC_009657), 1A (NC_010437). Other coronavirus sequences used in this study: HCoV-229E (AF304460), HCoV-OC43 (AY391777), HCoV-NL63 (AY567487), HKU1 (NC_006577), EMC (JX869059), FIPV (NC_002306), PRCV (DQ811787), BWCoV (NC_010646), MHV (AY700211), IBV (AY851295).
body_text.section: Sequence analysis and databank accession numbers ::: METHODS

body_text.text: Construction of expression clones for human and civet ACE2 in pcDNA3.1 has been described previously29. Bat ACE2 was amplified from a Rhinolophus sinicus (sample no. 3357). Briefly, total RNA was extracted from bat rectal tissue using RNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen). First-strand cDNA was synthesized from total RNA by reverse transcription with random hexamers. Full-length bat ACE2 fragments were amplified using forward primer bAF2 and reverse primer bAR229. The ACE2 gene was cloned into pCDNA3.1 with KpnI and XhoI, and verified by sequencing. Purified ACE2 plasmids were transfected to HeLa cells. After 24 h, lysates of HeLa cells expressing human, civet, or bat ACE2 were confirmed by western-blot or immunofluorescence assay (IFA).
body_text.section: Amplification, cloning and expression of the bat ACE2 gene ::: METHODS

body_text.text: Lysates of cells or filtered supernatants containing pseudoviruses were separated by 10% sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE), followed by transfer to a nitrocellulose membrane (Millipore). For detection of S protein, the membrane was incubated with rabbit anti-Rp3 S fragment aa 561–666 polyantibodies (1:200), and the bound antibodies were detected by AP-conjugated goat anti-rabbit IgG (1:1,000). For detection of HIV-1 p24 in supernatants, monoclonal antibody against HIV p24 (p24 MAb) was used as the primary antibody at a dilution of 1:1,000, followed by incubation with AP-conjugated goat anti-mouse IgG at the same dilution. To detect the expression of ACE2 in HeLa cells, goat antibody against the huACE2 ectodomain (1:500) was used as the first antibody, followed by incubation with HRP- conjugated donkey anti-goat IgG (1:1000).

Vero E6 cell monolayers were maintained in DMEM medium supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum (FCS). PCR-positive samples (in 200 μl buffer) were gradient centrifuged at 3,000–12,000 rpm, and supernatant were diluted 1:10 in DMEM medium before being added to Vero E6 cells. After incubation at 37°C for 1 h, inocula were removed and replaced with fresh DMEM medium with 2% FCS. Cells were incubated at 37°C for 3 days and checked daily for cytopathetic effect (CPE). Double dose triple antibiotics penicillin/streptomycin/amphotericin (Gibco) were included in all tissue culture media (penicillin 200 IU/ml, streptomycin 0.2 mg/ml, amphotericin 0.5 μg/ml). Three blind passages were carried out for each sample. After each passage, both the culture supernatant and cell pellet were examined for presence of virus by RT-PCR using primers targeting the RdRp or S gene. Virions in supernatant (10 ml) were collected and inactivated using 0.1% formaldehyde for 4 h, then concentrated by ultracentrifugation through a 20% sucrose cushion (5 ml) at 80,000g for 90 min using a Ty90 rotor (Beckman). The pelleted viral particles were dissolved in 100 μl phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), stained with 2% phosphtungstic acid (pH 7.0) and examined using a Tecnai transmission electron microscope (FEI) at 200 kV.

Cell lines used for this study and their culture conditions are summarized in Extended Data Table 5. Virus titer was determined in Vero E6 cells by CPE counts. Cell lines from different origins and HeLa cells expressing ACE2s from human (hACE2), civet (cACE2) or Chinese horseshoe bat (bACE2) were grown on coverslips in 24-well plates (Corning) incubated with bat SL-CoV-WIV1 at MOI=10 for 1 h. The inoculum was removed and washed twice with PBS and supplemented with medium. HeLa cells without ACE2 expression and Vero E6 cells were used as negative and positive controls, respectively. At 24 h post-infection, cells were washed with PBS and fixed with 4% formaldehyde in PBS (pH 7.4) for 20 min at 4°C. ACE2 expression was detected using goat anti-hACE2 immunoglobulin (Ig) (R&D Systems) followed by FITC-labeled donkey anti-goat Ig from PTGLab (Chicago, IL). Virus replication was detected using rabbit antibody against the SL-CoV Rp3 nucleocapsid protein followed by cyanin 3-conjugated mouse anti-rabbit IgG. Nuclei were stained with 4′,6′-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI). Staining patterns were examined using a FV1200 confocal microscope (Olympus).
body_text.section: Virus infectivity detected by IFA ::: METHODS

body_text.text: Vero E6, A549, PK15, RSKT, HeLa cells with or without expressing ACE2s of different origins were inoculated with 0.1 TCID50 WIV-1 and incubated for 1 h at 37°C. After removing the inoculum, the cells were cultured with medium containing 1% fetal bovine serum. Supernatants were collected at 0, 12, 24 and 48 h. RNA from 140 μl of each supernatant was extracted with the Viral RNA Mini Kit (Qiagen) following manufacturer’s instructions and eluted in 60 μl AVE buffer. RNA was quantified on the ABI StepOne™ system, with the TaqMan AgPath-ID™ One-Step RT-PCR Kit (Applied Biosystems) in a 25 μl reaction mix containing 4 μl RNA, 1 x RT-PCR enzyme mix, 1 x RT-PCR buffer, 40 pmol forward primer (5′-GTGGTGGTGACGGCAAAATG-3′), 40 pmol reverse primer (5′-AAGTGAAGCTTCTGGGCCAG-3′) and 12 pmol probe (5′-FAM-AAAGAGCTCAGCCCCAGATG-BHQ1-3′). Amplification parameters were 10 min at 50 °C, 10 min at 95 °C and 50 cycles of 15 s at 95 °C and 20 s at 60°C. RNA dilutions from purified WIV-1 stock were used as a standard.
body_text.section: Virus infectivity detected by Real-time RT-PCR ::: METHODS

body_text.text: SARS patient sera were inactivated at 56°C for 30 min and then used for virus neutralization testing. Sera were diluted starting with 1:10 and then serially 2-fold diluted in 96-well cell plates to 1:40. Each 100 μl serum dilution was mixed with 100 μl viral supernatant containing 100 TCID50 of WIV1 and incubated at 37°C for 1 h. The mixture was added in triplicate wells of 96-well cell plates with plated monolayers of Vero E6 cells and further incubated at 37°C for 2 days. Serum from a healthy blood donor was used as a negative control in each experiment. CPE was observed using an inverted microscope at 2 days post-inoculation. The neutralizing antibody titer was read as the highest dilution of serum which completely suppressed CPE in infected wells. The neutralization test was repeated twice.

Full-length genomic sequences of SL-CoV Rs3367 or SHC014 were aligned with those of selected SARS-CoVs and bat SL-CoVs using Clustal X. The aligned sequences were preliminarily scanned for recombination events using Recombination Detection Program (RDP) 4.019. The potential recombination events suggested by RDP due to their strong P-values (<10–20) were further investigated by similarity plot and bootscan analyses implemented in Simplot 3.5.1. Phylogenetic origin of the major and minor parental regions of the 3367 or SHC014 were constructed from the concatenated sequences of the essential ORFs of the major and minor parental regions of selected SARS-CoV and SL-CoVs. Two genome regions between three estimated breakpoints (20,827–26,553, and 26,554–28,685) were aligned independently using ClustalX and generated two alignments of 5,727 bp and 2,133 bp. The two alignments were used to construct maximum likehood trees to better infer the fragment parents. All nucleotide numberings in this study are based on 3367 genome position.

TABREF0.text: Extended Data Table 1: Summary of sampling detail and CoV prevalence

TABREF1.text: Extended Data Table 2: Genomic sequence identities of the two novel bat SL-CoVs (RsSHC014 and Rs3367) with SARS-CoVs from human (GZ02, BJ01, Tor2) and civet (SZ3), as well as previously identified bat SL-CoVs in China (Rp3, Rf1, Rm1, Rs672, HKU3-1) and Europe (BM48-31)

TABREF2.text: Extended Data Table 3: Genomic annotation and comparison of bat SL-CoV Rs3367 with human/civet SARS-CoVs and other bat SL-CoVs. The ORFs in the genome were predicted and potential protein sequences were translated. Pairwise comparisons were conducted for all ORFs at nucleotide (nt) and amino acid (aa) levels. The s2m were compared at nt level. TRS: Transcription regulating-sequences; N/D, not done; N/A, not available

TABREF3.text: Extended Data Table 4: Genomic annotation and comparison of bat SL-CoV RsSHC014 with human/civet SARS-CoVs and other bat SL-CoVs. The ORFs in the genome were predicted and potential protein sequences were translated. Pairwise comparisons were conducted for all ORFs at nucleotide acids (nt) and amino acids (aa) levels. The s2m were compared at nt level. TRS: Transcription regulating-sequences; N/D, not done; N/A, not available

TABREF4.text: Extended Data Table 5: Cell lines used for virus isolation and susceptibility tests

FIGREF0.text: Figure 1: a, SARS-CoV S protein aa residues 310 to 520 were aligned with homologous regions of bat SL-CoVs using the ClustalW software. A maximum-likelihood phylogenetic tree was constructed using Poisson model with bootstrap values determined by 1,000 replicates in the MEGA5 software package. The RBD sequences identified in this study are in bold and named by the sample numbers. The key amino acids residues involved in interacting with human ACE2 molecule are indicated on the right of tree. SARS-CoV GZ02, BJ01 and Tor2 were isolated from patients of early, middle and late phase, respectively, during the SARS outbreak in 2003. SARS-CoV SZ3 was identified from Paguma larvata in 2003 collected in Guangdong, China. SL-CoV Rp3, Rs_672 and HKU3-1 were identified from Rhinolophus sinicus collected in China (respectively: Guangxi, 2004; Guizhou, 2006; and Hong Kong, 2005). Rf1 and Rm1 were identified from R. ferrumequinum and R. macrotis, respectively, collected in Hubei, China, in 2004. Bat SARS-related CoV BM48-31 was identified from R. blasii collected in Bulgaria in 2008. BtCoV_HKU9-1 was identified from Rousettus leschenaultii collected in Guangdong, China in 2005/2006 and used as an outgroup. Filled triangles, circles, and diamond indicate samples with co-infection by two different SL-CoVs. – indicates the amino acid deletion. b, Phylogenetic origins of the two parental regions of 3367 or SHC014. ML phylogenetic trees were constructed from alignments of two fragments covering nt 20,827–26,533 (5,727 nt) and nt 26,534–28,685(2,133 bp) of the 3367 genome, respectively. For display purpose, the trees were midpoint rooted. The taxa were annotated according to strain names: SARS-CoV, SARS coronavirus; SARS-like CoV, bat SARS-like coronavirus. The two novel SL-CoV, 3367 and SHC014, are in bold and italics.

FIGREF1.text: Figure 2: Virions from a 10-ml culture were collected, inactivated and concentrated/purified by sucrose gradient centrifugation. The pelleted viral particles were dissolved in 100 μl PBS, stained with 2% phosphtungstic acid (pH 7.0) and examined directly using a Tecnai transmission electron microscope (FEI) at 200 kV.

FIGREF2.text: Figure 3: Determination of virus infectivity in HeLa cells with and without the expression of ACE2 (abbreviations: h, human; c, civet; and b, bat). ACE2 expression was detected with goat anti-humanACE2 antibody followed by FITC-conjugated donkey anti-goat IgG. Virus replication was detected with rabbit antibody against the SL-CoV Rp3 nucleocapsid protein followed by Cy3-conjugated mouse anti-rabbit IgG. Nucleus was stained with DAPI. The columns (from left to right) show staining of nuclei (blue), ACE2 expression (green), virus replication (red), merged triple-stained images and real-time PCR results, respectively. (n = 3). Error bars represent standard deviation.

FIGREF3.text: Figure 4: Virus infection in A549, RSKT, Vero E6 and PK15 cells. Virus replication was detected as described for Figure 4. The columns (from left to right) show staining of nuclei (blue), virus replication (red), merged double-stained images and real-time PCR results, respectively. (n = 3). Error bars represent standard deviation.

FIGREF4.text: Extended Data Figure 1: SARS-CoV S protein (aa 310 to 520) is aligned with homologous regions of bat SL-CoVs using the ClustalW. The newly discovered bat SL-CoVs are indicated with a bold vertical line on the left. The key amino acids residues involved in interacting with human ACE2 molecule are numbered on the top of the aligned sequences.

FIGREF5.text: Extended Data Figure 2: Alignment of S1 sequences (aa 1–660) of the two novel bat SL-CoV S proteins with those of previously reported bat SL-CoVs and human and civet SARS-CoVs. The newly discovered bat SL-CoVs are boxed in red. SARS-CoV GZ02, BJ01 and Tor2 were isolated from patients of early, middle and late phase, respectively, of the SARS outbreak in 2003. SARS-CoV SZ3 was identified from Paguma larvata in 2003 collected in Guangdong, China. SL-CoV Rp3, Rs_672 and HKU3-1 were identified from Rhinolophus sinicus collected in Guangxi, Guizhou and Hong Kong, China, respectively. Rf1 and Rm1 were identified from R. ferrumequinum and R. macrotis, respectively, collected in Hubei Province, China. Bat SARS-related CoV BM48-31 was identified from R. blasii collected in Bulgaria.

FIGREF6.text: Extended Data Figure 3: Phylogenetic tree of bat SL-CoVs and SARS-CoVs based on complete RdRp sequences (2796 nt). Bat SL-CoV-SHC014 and 3367 are highlighted by filled circles. Three established coronaivirus genera, Alphacoronavirus, Betacoronavirus, Gammacoronavirus are marked as α, β and γ, respectively. Four CoV groups in genus Betacoronavirus are indicated as A, B, C and D, respectively. MHV: Murine hepatitis virus, PHEV: Porcine hemagglutinating encephalomyelitis virus, PRCV: Porcine respiratory coronavirus, Feline Infectious Virus, Infectious bronchitis coronavirus, Beluga Whale coronavirus.

FIGREF7.text: Extended Data Figure 4: Phylogenetic tree of bat SL-CoVs and SARS-CoVs based on complete S protein sequences (1256 aa). Bat SL-CoV-SHC014 and 3367 are highlighted by filled circles. Bat CoV HKU9 was used as an outgroup.

FIGREF8.text: Extended Data Figure 5: Detection of potential recombination events. Similarity plot (a) and bootscan analysis (b) detected three recombination breakpoints in the bat SL-CoV Rs3367 or SHC014 genome. The three breakpoints were located at ORF1b (nt 20,827), M (nt 26,553) and N (nt 28,685) gene, respectively. Both analyses were performed with an F84 distance model, a window size of 1,500 bp and a step size of 300 bp.
